priority_recommendations.recommendation: The identifier may conform to a UUID or HASH syntax, although a globally unique identifier (GUID) is preferable. A GUID is unique, irrespective of the context.
Describe your data with core descriptive metadata elements.
Include machine readable data access information to your metadata.
Make parsable graph metadata available via content negotiation or typed links.
Include the variable your data measures to your metadata.
In the metadata, specify a file size that match the data content being described.
In the metadata, define measured variables and observation types that match those of the data content.
Make your metadata conformant to a standard provenance schema (e.g., PROV-O or PAV).

F1.principle_name: (meta)data are assigned a globally unique and persistent identifier.

F1-01D.metric_name: Data is assigned a globally unique identifier.

F1-01D-1.test_name: Identifier may conform to an UUID or HASH type syntax.
F1-01D-1.result_description: Identifier did not conform to an UUID or HASH type syntax.
F1-01D-1.recommendation: The identifier may conform to a UUID or HASH syntax, although a globally unique identifier (GUID) is preferable. A GUID is unique, irrespective of the context.
F1-01D-1.recommendation_details: These identifiers are not, however, guaranteed to be globally unique: some other resource might have the same identifier. For a higher degree of FAIRness, consider defining an identifier that is guaranteed to globally uniquely identify a particular resource irrespective of the context, i.e., no distinct object has the same identifier.
F1-01D-1.losses: Without a unique identifier of any kind, there is no guarantee that resources with the same identifier provisioned by different sources represent the same subject.

F1-01D-2.test_name: Identifier should conform to a defined unique identifier syntax.
F1-01D-2.result_description: Identifier follows a defined unique identifier syntax (doi).
F1-01D-2.recommendation: Define globally unique identifier (GUID) for the resources, i.e., an identifier that is unique irrespective of the context.
F1-01D-2.recommendation_details: Define identifiers guaranteed to globally uniquely identify a particular resource irrespective of the context, i.e., no distinct object has the same identifier. Examples of GUID are URL, PURL, DOI, ARK, and Handle System ID. The use of GUID results in Advanced maturity level. As an alternative, you can use a UUID or Hash; however, they do not ensure uniqueness irrespective of context, which results in an Initial maturity level.
F1-01D-2.losses: Without a globally unique identifier, there is no guarantee that resources with the same identifier provisioned by different sources represent the same subject.

F1-02D.metric_name: Data is assigned a persistent identifier.

F1-02D-1.test_name: Identifier URL should resolve to a landing page.
F1-02D-1.result_description: Identifier URL resolved to a landing page.
F1-02D-1.recommendation: Create identifiers that are resolvable, e.g., resolve to a landing page.
F1-02D-1.recommendation_details: The identifier should be resolvable, i.e., if you make a get request on the identifier, you receive a landing page with metadata containing further information on how to access the data content. In some cases, the identifier may resolve to a downloadable artifact, or none if the data or repository is no longer maintained. It is a best practice to have a PID resolve to a landing page instead of its actual content.
F1-02D-1.losses: Without a resolvable identifier, it is more difficult to access the resource's content.

F1-02D-2.test_name: Identifier should conform to a defined persistent identifier syntax.
F1-02D-2.result_description: Identifier conformed to a defined persistent identifier syntax.
F1-02D-2.recommendation: Create identifiers that are Globally Unique, Persistent, and Resolvable (GUPRI).
F1-02D-2.recommendation_details: Define identifiers that are guaranteed to remain valid over a period of time ensured by an institutional commitment, e.g., PURL, DOI, ARK, Handle System ID, etc. Besides persistence, the identifier should be resolvable, i.e., if you make a get request on the identifier, you receive a landing page with metadata containing further information on how to access the data content. In some cases, the identifier may resolve to a downloadable artifact, or none if the data or repository is no longer maintained. Note that although a URL is a GUID, it may not be persistent since the resource may not be accessible (link rot problem) or the resource available under the original URL may be changed (content drift problem). A Globally Unique, Persistent, and Resolvable Identifier (GRUPI) is considered optimal for FAIR compliance. It is a best practice to have a PID resolve to a landing page instead of its actual content.
F1-02D-2.losses: Without persistent identifier (PID), there is no guarantee that the resource remains stable and resolvable for the long term.

F2.principle_name: Data are described with rich metadata.

F2-01M.metric_name: Metadata includes descriptive core elements to support findability

F2-01M-1.result_details: Found required core citation metadata elements: ['creator', 'title', 'object_identifier', 'publication_date', 'publisher', 'object_type'].
F2-01M-1.recommendation: Describe your data with citation metadata elements.
F2-01M-1.recommendation_details: Describe your data with citation metadata elements, such as object identifier, object type, title, publisher, and publication date. The citation metadata is domain-agnostic defined from guidelines and recommendations in the literature.
F2-01M-1.losses: Without citation metadata, resources would not have the minimum information that enables citation.

F2-01M-2.test_name: Core descriptive metadata should be available.
F2-01M-2.result_description: Core descriptive metadata was not available.
F2-01M-2.result_details: Not all required core descriptive metadata were found.The following ones are missing: ['keywords'].
F2-01M-2.recommendation: Describe your data with core descriptive metadata elements.
F2-01M-2.recommendation_details: Describe your data with core metadata elements, such as object identifier, object type, title, publisher, publication date, summary, and keywords. The core metadata is the minimum descriptive information required to enable data finding, including citation, which makes it easier to find data. They are domain-agnostic defined from guidelines and recommendations in the literature.
F2-01M-2.losses: Without core descriptive metadata, resources would not have the minimum information that enables finding.

F3.principle_name: Metadata clearly and explicitly include the identifier of the data it describes.

F3-01M.metric_name: Metadata includes the identifier of the data it describes.

F3-01M-1.test_name: Metadata should clearly and explicitly include the identifier of the data it describes.
F3-01M-1.result_description: Metadata included the identifier of the data it describes.
F3-01M-1.recommendation: Include an identifier of the described data in the metadata.
F3-01M-1.recommendation_details: Describe data with metadata that explicitly specifies the identifier of the data. Users should be able to discover and access the data through the metadata. Currently, 2BFAIRevaluates metadata serialized using schema.org in JSON-LD. For this metric it checks if the used schema.org type is 'dataset' and if the property 'distribution' is present in the metadata.
F3-01M-1.losses: Without an identifier to the described data, it becomes more difficult to find.

F3-02M.metric_name: Metadata includes an identifier to the metadata itself.

F3-02M-1.test_name: Metadata may clearly and explicitly include the identifier to the metadata itself.
F3-02M-1.result_description: Metadata included an identifier to the metadata itself.
F3-02M-1.recommendation: Include in the metadata an identifier of the metadata itself.
F3-02M-1.recommendation_details: Describe data with metadata that explicitly specifies the identifier of the metadata itself. Users should be able to discover and access the metadata through the metadata. For this metric 2BFAIR checks if the string corresponding to the metadata identifier is present in a term of the metadata
F3-02M-1.losses: Without an identifier to the digital resource in the metadata, it becomes more difficult to find.

F4.principle_name: Metadata are registered or indexed in a searcheable source.

F4-01M.metric_name: Metadata are offered in such a way that they can be retrieved by machines.

F4-01M-1.test_name: Metadata should be offered in such a way that they can be retrieved by machines.
F4-01M-1.result_description: Metadata were offered in such a way that they could be retrieved by machines.
F4-01M-1.result_details: Metadata is given in JSON-LD which can be ingested in the catalogs of major search engines.
F4-01M-1.recommendation: Expose your metadata in such a way that they can be retrieved by machines.
F4-01M-1.recommendation_details: Metadata of the digital object should be retrievable programmatically through at least one method being exposed as, e.g., structured data embedded in the landing page of the data object (e.g., using JSON-LD), through typed links of metadata document or signposting header links, through content negotiation with a PID provider service. Currently, 2BFAIR checks if the metadata is available in JSON-LD.
F4-01M-1.losses: Without machine retrievable metadata, the dataset becomes more difficult to automatically assess.

A1.principle_name: (meta)data are retrievable by their identifier using a standardized communications protocol.

A1-01M.metric_name: Metadata contains access level and access conditions of the data.

A1-01M-1.test_name: Information about access restrictions or rights can be identified in metadata.
A1-01M-1.result_description: Information about access restrictions or rights was identified in metadata.
A1-01M-1.recommendation: Add to the metadata information on access level and conditions of the data.
A1-01M-1.recommendation_details: This information will specify if the access level to the data is public, embargoed, restricted or if access is allowed only to the metadata.
A1-01M-1.losses: Information on the access level and conditions of the are necessary to gain access to the data.

A1-01M-2.test_name: Data access information is machine readable.
A1-01M-2.result_description: Data access information is not machine readable.
A1-01M-2.recommendation: Include machine readable data access information to your metadata.
A1-01M-2.losses: Without machine readable data access information, the access rights to your metadata may be more difficult to recover.

A1-02M.metric_name: Metadata is accessible through a standardized communication protocol.

A1-02M-1.test_name: Landing page link is based on standardized web communication protocols.
A1-02M-1.result_description: Landing page link is based on standardized web communication protocols.
A1-02M-1.recommendation: Use a link for your landing page that is based on a standardized web communications protocol.
A1-02M-1.recommendation_details: Some standardized web communications protocols are http, https and ftp.
A1-02M-1.losses: Without a landing page link based on standardized web communication protocols, accessing the landing page may be more difficult.

A1-03D.metric_name: Metadata includes a resolvable link to data based on standardized web communication protocols.

A1-03D-1.test_name: Link to data is based on standardized web communication protocols.
A1-03D-1.result_description: Link to data is based on standardized web communication protocols.
A1-03D-1.recommendation: Use a link for your data that is based on a standardized web communications protocol.
A1-03D-1.recommendation_details: Some standardized web communications protocols are http, https and ftp.
A1-03D-1.losses: Without a link to the data based on standardized web communication protocols, accessing the data may be more difficult.

I1.principle_name: (meta)data use a formal, accessible, shared, and broadly applicable language for knowledge representation.

I1-01M.metric_name: Metadata is represented using a formal knowledge representation language.

I1-01M-1.test_name: Parsable, structured metadata (JSON-LD, RDFa) is embedded in the landing page XHTML/HTML code.
I1-01M-1.result_description: Parsable, structured metadata is embedded in the landing page code.
I1-01M-1.recommendation: Embed parsable, structured metadata in the landing page code
I1-01M-1.losses: Without parsable metadata, machines will be unable to process the data it in a meaningful way, reducing data exchange possibilities.

I1-01M-2.test_name: Parsable, graph data (RDF, JSON-LD) is accessible through content negotiation or typed links.
I1-01M-2.result_description: Parsable, graph metadata were not accessible via content negotiation or typed links.
I1-01M-2.recommendation: Make parsable graph metadata available via content negotiation or typed links.
I1-01M-2.recommendation_details: You can make parsable graph metadata available via rdf-type-linked, rdf-signposting-linked, schemaorg-negotiated, rdf-negotiated.
I1-01M-2.losses: Without parsable metadata, machines will be unable to process the data it in a meaningful way, reducing data exchange possibilities.

I2.principle_name: (Meta)data use vocabularies that follow FAIR principles

I2-01M-1.test_name: Vocabulary namespace URIs can be identified in metadata
I2-01M-1.result_description: Schema.org was identified as the vocabulary used for the metadata.
I2-01M-1.recommendation: Use schema.org as the vocabulary to convey your metadata.
I2-01M-1.losses: Without a vocabulary namespace, we do not know the origin of a term, which can lead to ambiguity and makes the data search difficult.

R1.principle_name: Metadata are richly described with a plurality of accurate and relevant attributes.

R1-01MD.metric_name: Metadata specifies the content of the data.

R1-01MD-1.test_name: Minimal information about available data content is given in metadata.
R1-01MD-1.result_description: Minimal information about available data content was given in metadata.
R1-01MD-1.recommendation: Include minimal information about the data content in the metadata.
R1-01MD-1.recommendation_details: Some of the minimal information that can be included are size and type for the data.
R1-01MD-1.losses: Without minimal information, possible users of the data may have very little knowledge about it, making it more difficult to reuse.

R1-01MD-2.test_name: File type and size are specified in metadata.
R1-01MD-2.result_description: File type and size were specified in metadata.
R1-01MD-2.recommendation: Include file size and type information to your metadata.
R1-01MD-2.losses: Without information on the size and type of the data, it may be more difficult to reuse.

R1-01MD-3.test_name: Measured variable is specified in the metadata.
R1-01MD-3.result_description: Measured variable was not specified in the metadata.
R1-01MD-3.recommendation: Include the variable your data measures to your metadata.
R1-01MD-3.losses: Without information on the variable measured by the data, it may be more difficult to reuse.

R1-01MD-4.test_name: Data content matches file type specified in metadata.
R1-01MD-4.result_description: Data content matched file type specified in metadata.
R1-01MD-4.recommendation: In the metadata, specify a file type that matches the data content being described.
R1-01MD-4.recommendation_details: Check the data content file format, and add this values to the metadata.
R1-01MD-4.losses: Inaccurate metadata may not reflect properties of the data content that are interesting to possible users, reducing reuse of the data.

R1-01MD-5.test_name: Data content matches file size specified in metadata.
R1-01MD-5.result_description: Data content did not match file size specified in metadata.
R1-01MD-5.recommendation: In the metadata, specify a file size that match the data content being described.
R1-01MD-5.recommendation_details: Check the data content file size, and add this value to the metadata.
R1-01MD-5.losses: Inaccurate metadata may not reflect properties of the data content that are interesting to possible users, reducing reuse of the data.

R1-01MD-6.test_name: Data content matches measured variables or observation types specified in metadata.
R1-01MD-6.result_description: Data content did not match measured variables or observation types specified in metadata.
R1-01MD-6.recommendation: In the metadata, define measured variables and observation types that match those of the data content.
R1-01MD-6.losses: Inaccurate metadata may not reflect properties of the data content that are interesting to possible users, reducing reuse of the data.

R1.1.principle_name: Metadata and data are released with a clear and accessible data usage license.

R1.1-01M.metric_name: Metadata and data are released with a clear and accessible data usage license.

R1.1-01M-1.test_name: Metadata and data are released with a clear and accessible data usage license.
R1.1-01M-1.result_description: Metadata and data have been released with a clear and accessible data usage license.
R1.1-01M-1.recommendation: Include a clear data usage license to your data and metadata.
R1.1-01M-1.losses: Without a clear usage license, users will be unsure if they are allowed to use your data and metadata.

R1.2.principle_name: Metadata are associated with detailed provenance information.

R1.2-01M.metric_name: Metadata are associated with detailed provenance information.

R1.2-01M-1.test_name: Metadata should include provenance information about data creation or generation.
R1.2-01M-1.result_description: Metadata included provenance information about data creation or generation.
R1.2-01M-1.recommendation: Add provenance information to your metadata.
R1.2-01M-1.recommendation_details: Currently, we are evaluating creator and publishing (publisher and datePublished) as the minimum required provenance. Provenance data (also known as lineage) represents a dataset's history, including the people, entities, and processes involved in its creation, management and longer-term curation. It is essential that data producers provide provenance information about the data to enable informed use and reuse. The levels of provenance information needed can vary depending on the data type (e.g., measurement, observation, derived data, or data product) and research domains. We suggest to include provenance properties related to: (i) Sources of data, e.g., datasets the data is derived from and instruments; (ii) Data creation or collection date; (iii) Contributors involved in data creation and their roles; and (iv) Data publication, modification and versioning information. There are various ways through which provenance information may be included in a metadata record (Devaraju et al., 2022).
R1.2-01M-1.losses: Without provenance data, it is not clear the lineage (i.e, history) about the produced data which hampers use and reuse.

R1.2-01M-2.test_name: Metadata contains provenance information using formal provenance ontologies (PROV-O).
R1.2-01M-2.result_description: Test not executed: No metadata record found.
R1.2-01M-2.result_details: Test not executed: Accepted Metadata Schemas were not found.
R1.2-01M-2.recommendation: Make your metadata conformant to a standard provenance schema (e.g., PROV-O or PAV).
R1.2-01M-2.recommendation_details: Provenance data (also known as lineage) represents a dataset's history, including the people, entities, and processes involved in its creation, management and longer-term curation. It is essential that data producers provide provenance information about the data to enable informed use and reuse. There are various ways through which provenance information may be included in a metadata record (Devaraju et al., 2022). We are evaluating the use of PROV-O and PAV.
R1.2-01M-2.losses: Without using a standard schema to convey provenance information, it is not machine-readable.

R1.3-01M.metric_name: Metadata follows a standard recommended by the target research community of the data.

R1.3-01M-1.test_name: Multidisciplinary but community endorsed metadata standards can be detected by namespace.
R1.3-01M-1.result_description: Multidisciplinary but community endorsed metadata standards were not detected.
R1.3-01M-1.recommendation: Multidisciplinary metadata standards should be used to encode your data to foster reusability.
R1.3-01M-1.recommendation_details: Elicit the multidisciplinary metadata standard employed by your community, and use them to encode your metadata. Currently, we are evaluating the use of schema.org.
R1.3-01M-1.losses: Without the use of multidisciplinary metadata standard, other groups in multidisciplinary communities are not able to reuse your data.

R1.3-01M-2.test_name: Community specific metadata standard can be detected using namespaces or schemas found in provided metadata.
R1.3-01M-2.result_description: Community-specific metadata standard were not detected using namespaces or schemas found in provided metadata.
R1.3-01M-2.recommendation: Community-specific metadata should be used to encode your data to foster reusability of your data by your community.
R1.3-01M-2.recommendation_details: Elicit the specific metadata employed by your community and use than to encode your metadata. Some communities have well-established metadata standards (e.g., geospatial: ISO19115; biodiversity: DarwinCore, ABCD, EML; social science: DDI; astronomy: International Virtual Observatory Alliance Technical Specifications) while others have limited standards or standards that are under development (e.g., engineering and linguistics) (Devaraju et al., 2022).
R1.3-01M-2.losses: Without community-specific metadata, the specific details of your community are not considered when convey metadata values and in your community is not able to reuse your data.

R1.3-02D.metric_name: Data is available in a file format recommended by the target research community.

R1.3-02D-1.test_name: The format of a data file given in the metadata is listed in the long term file formats, open file formats or scientific file formats controlled list.
R1.3-02D-1.result_description: Data file format is either scientific, long term, or open.
R1.3-02D-1.recommendation: Expose your data in a file format that is recognized by the target community.
R1.3-02D-1.recommendation_details: File formats recognized by the community may be long term, scientific or open.
R1.3-02D-1.losses: Exposing your data in a file format not recognized by the community may make it harder for members of the community to reuse the data.

evaluated_metadata.name: Widespread Tephra geochemistry, Lake Motosu Site MOT15-2 age model, and Mt. Fuji eruption ages

publisher.name: PANGAEA
publisher.disambiguatingDescription: Data Publisher for Earth & Environmental Science

includedInDataCatalog.name: PANGAEA
includedInDataCatalog.disambiguatingDescription: Data Publisher for Earth & Environmental Science

evaluated_metadata.description: An 8,000-year lacustrine sediment record from Lake Motosu (Fuji Five Lakes) records several eruptions, including potentially unreported events, of the active Mt. Fuji volcano, which receives approximately 47 million annual visitors. A high-fidelity age model is constructed from tephra ages and high-density radiocarbon dating of terrestrial macrofossil and bulk organic matter. Variability in lake reservoir age is constrained by modern lake water radiocarbon measurement and reverse calibration of tephra calendar ages. We present more accurate ages for known eruptions, detect a wider distribution of ejecta for the most recent summit eruption, and potentially identify previously undetected flank eruptions. There are closely spaced scoria-fall layers that may be difficult to differentiate as separate events in land-based surveys. These results demonstrate the utility of lacustrine sediments as powerful tools for understanding characteristics of volcanic eruptions.
evaluated_metadata.abstract: An 8,000-year lacustrine sediment record from Lake Motosu (Fuji Five Lakes) records several eruptions, including potentially unreported events, of the active Mt. Fuji volcano, which receives approximately 47 million annual visitors. A high-fidelity age model is constructed from tephra ages and high-density radiocarbon dating of terrestrial macrofossil and bulk organic matter. Variability in lake reservoir age is constrained by modern lake water radiocarbon measurement and reverse calibration of tephra calendar ages. We present more accurate ages for known eruptions, detect a wider distribution of ejecta for the most recent summit eruption, and potentially identify previously undetected flank eruptions. There are closely spaced scoria-fall layers that may be difficult to differentiate as separate events in land-based surveys. These results demonstrate the utility of lacustrine sediments as powerful tools for understanding characteristics of volcanic eruptions.

citation.name: Standards run during analysis to verify EPMA output

isBasedOn.name: Mt. Fuji Holocene eruption history reconstructed from proximal lake sediments and high-density radiocarbon dating
